text_headers: Thousands take part in Texas Rally for Life at Capitol
text: Thousands take part in Texas Rally for Life at CapitolNews Sports Hookem.com Austin360 Opinion Advertise Obituaries eNewspaper Legals  LOCALThousands take part in Texas Rally for Life at CapitolHeather Osbourne, hosbourne@statesman.comCarl Johnson was one among more than 5,000 anti-abortion activists to march Saturday toward the Capitol during the Texas Rally for Life in the name of “peace, love and God.”Johnson, holding one of four of his children at Saturday’s event, said he chose to travel to Austin from his home in Spring Branch near San Antonio for the rally in hopes of one day ending abortions in the United States.“We’re here to support life,” Johnson said. “When children are born, they change your life. I’m here because my life was changed through my kids. We’re here for peace. We’re here for love. We’re here to spread God’s love to everybody.”Anti-abortion demonstrators kicked off the event at 1 p.m. at the intersection of 14th Street and San Jacinto Boulevard with a march to the Capitol.State Rep. Jeff Leach; U.S. Rep. Chip Roy; and Sylvia B. Johnson-Matthews, the Houston Pregnancy Help Center’s chief executive officer, were just a few of the speakers who spoke during the rally that followed.Claire Culwell, who introduced herself to the crowd as an abortion survivor, also spoke at Saturday’s rally about her journey to find her birth mother, which she said ended with the revelation that her twin died from the abortion.“I can tell you what it felt like to look into my birth mother’s eyes and realized I survived something that was meant to take my life, and that I was walking around every single day for 21 years not knowing I was a twin-less twin in the name of choice,” Culwell said.“There is a face, a name and a story with that unborn baby,” she continued. “Today, when you look at my face, you are literally looking at my twin. You are literally looking at that unborn child.”Amy O’Donnell, communications director for Texas Rally for Life, said the mission of the annual event was to “show the media and our elected officials that Texas is pro-life.”O’Donnell said it was also to commemorate the 47th anniversary of Roe v. Wade, the landmark U.S. Supreme Court decision that established a woman’s legal right to an abortion.Texas Department of Public Safety troopers estimated the crowd size Saturday as being between 5,000 to 6,000 people. A handful of abortion rights supporters also briefly stood at the front gates of the Capitol before the rally began.The Texas rally comes a day after President Donald Trump made history as the first sitting president to attend the March for Life rally in Washington.During Trump’s speech Friday, he said the event’s mission was to “defend the right of every child born and unborn, to fulfill their God-given potential.”“Young people are the heart of the March for Life,” Trump said. “It’s your generation that is making America the pro-family, pro-life nation."Miles Sheahan, who held a sign Saturday at the Austin rally that read “My generation will end abortion,” echoed Trump’s remarks.
